questions.text: The marked structure in the diagram is involved with motor activites. It receives afferents from all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Spinal cord. The marked structure in the diagram is likely the basal ganglia, a key brain structure involved in motor control. The basal ganglia receive input from various parts of the brain, but they do not receive direct afferent input from the spinal cord. Instead, they receive input from the cerebral cortex and thalamus, among other structures, to help modulate motor activities. The spinal cord primarily transmits motor signals to muscles, and while it does communicate with the brain, it does not provide direct input to the basal ganglia. Incorrect Responses: B. Thalamus The thalamus is a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex. It sends afferent signals to the basal ganglia, which is involved in motor regulation. Therefore, the thalamus does contribute afferent input to the basal ganglia. C. Cerebral cortex The cerebral cortex plays a major role in initiating voluntary movement and sends afferent input to the basal ganglia to influence motor control. It communicates with the basal ganglia to help regulate fine motor actions, making this input crucial for motor activities. D. Substantia nigra The substantia nigra is part of the brain's motor control system and provides important dopaminergic input to the basal ganglia, particularly the striatum. This input helps modulate motor control and coordination, so the substantia nigra is involved in afferent signaling to the basal ganglia.

choices.text: Loss of sensation from the floor of mouth
Loss of taste sensation in posterior 1/3rd of tongue

questions.text: Which of the following clinical finding is not seen in lesions of structures passing through jugular foramen:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Loss of sensation from the floor of mouth. Lesions involving structures passing through the jugular foramen typically affect the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), vagus nerve (CN X), and accessory nerve (CN XI). These structures are responsible for several functions such as motor control of the palate, sensation from the tongue, taste sensation, and the ability to shrug the shoulder. However, the floor of the mouth is primarily innervated by the lingual nerve, which is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), a branch of the trigeminal nerve. Therefore, loss of sensation from the floor of the mouth is not a typical feature of a lesion affecting structures passing through the jugular foramen. Incorrect Responses: A. Palatal paralysis The vagus nerve (CN X), which passes through the jugular foramen, is responsible for innervating the muscles of the palate, including the levator veli palatini. A lesion of the vagus nerve can lead to palatal paralysis, manifesting as difficulty in elevating the soft palate and the appearance of a uvular deviation to the unaffected side. Therefore, palatal paralysis is a typical clinical finding in jugular foramen lesions. B. Difficulty in shrugging of shoulder The accessory nerve (CN XI), which also passes through the jugular foramen, innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles, which are essential for shoulder shrugging. A lesion to this nerve leads to weakness or inability to shrug the shoulder. Thus, difficulty in shrugging the shoulder is a common clinical finding in jugular foramen lesions. D. Loss of taste sensation in posterior 1/3rd of tongue The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which passes through the jugular foramen, is responsible for taste sensation in the posterior third of the tongue. Lesions affecting this nerve can result in loss of taste sensation in this region. Therefore, loss of taste sensation in the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue is a typical finding in lesions of structures passing through the jugular foramen.

questions.text: Dorello’s canal transmits:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Abducent nerve. Dorello's canal is a small bony canal located at the base of the skull, and it transmits the abducent nerve (cranial nerve VI). The abducent nerve is responsible for innervating the lateral rectus muscle, which controls the lateral movement of the eye. The nerve passes through Dorello's canal on its way to the eye, making this the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: A. Middle meningeal artery The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery and passes through the foramen spinosum. It does not pass through Dorello's canal. Therefore, this option is incorrect. B. Mandibular nerve The mandibular nerve (V3) is the third branch of the trigeminal nerve and exits the skull via the foramen ovale. It does not pass through Dorello's canal. Hence, this is not the correct answer. C. Superior alveolar branch of maxillary The superior alveolar nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve (V2), provides sensory innervation to the upper teeth and gums. This nerve passes through the infraorbital foramen and is not associated with Dorello's canal.

questions.text: Artery lying deep to marked area in the given Pic is branch of which of the following artery.?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Maxillary Artery. The artery lying deep to the marked area in the given picture is most likely the inferior alveolar artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery. The maxillary artery is one of the two terminal branches of the external carotid artery, and it supplies deep structures in the face, including the muscles of mastication, teeth, and other structures in the deep facial region. The inferior alveolar artery specifically supplies the lower teeth and passes through the mandibular foramen, deep to the area in question. Incorrect Responses: A. Ophthalmic Artery The ophthalmic artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery and supplies the structures in the orbit and around the eye. It does not contribute to the arterial supply of the regions deep to the marked area in the jaw or face. Therefore, this option is incorrect. C. Internal Carotid Artery While the internal carotid artery gives rise to several important branches, such as the ophthalmic artery, it does not directly supply the deep structures of the face. The maxillary artery, a branch of the external carotid artery, is more involved in the arterial supply of the face. Thus, the internal carotid artery is not responsible for the artery in question. D. External Carotid Artery The external carotid artery gives rise to several branches that supply the face and neck, including the maxillary artery. However, the specific artery in question is a branch of the maxillary artery, not the external carotid artery directly. Therefore, while the external carotid artery is related to the maxillary artery, it is not the correct answer here.

questions.text: Lateral wall of cavernous contains all of the following nerves except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Abducent. The abducent nerve (cranial nerve VI) does not lie in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. Instead, it runs in close proximity to the cavernous sinus, but it passes through its superior petrosal sinus and enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure. While the abducent nerve is related to the cavernous sinus, it is not located in its lateral wall. This makes option D the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: A. Oculomotor The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) passes through the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. It innervates most of the extraocular muscles and the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which control eye movement. Therefore, the oculomotor nerve is correctly located in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. B. Maxillary The maxillary nerve (V2), a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), passes through the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. It provides sensory innervation to the mid-face, including the cheeks, upper lip, and upper teeth. Therefore, the maxillary nerve is correctly located in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. C. Ophthalmic The ophthalmic nerve (V1), another branch of the trigeminal nerve, also passes through the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. It provides sensory innervation to the forehead, scalp, and eyes. Therefore, the ophthalmic nerve is correctly located in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus.

choices.text: Greater wing and lesser wing of sphenoid
Greater wing and body of sphenoid
Lesser wing and body of sphenoid
Lesser wing of sphenoid and ethmoid

questions.text: The optic foramen is located between
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lesser wing and body of sphenoid. The optic foramen, also known as the optic canal, is located between the lesser wing and the body of the sphenoid bone. It allows the passage of the optic nerve (cranial nerve II) and the ophthalmic artery from the orbit to the middle cranial fossa. The optic foramen is critical for the visual pathway as it connects the eye to the brain. This anatomical location is well-defined and lies within the boundaries of the sphenoid bone, specifically between the lesser wing and the body. Incorrect Options: A. Greater wing and lesser wing of sphenoid: The greater wing and lesser wing of the sphenoid bone are separated by a significant gap, but this is not the location of the optic foramen. The space between the greater and lesser wings is occupied by other structures, such as the superior orbital fissure, not the optic foramen. B. Greater wing and body of sphenoid: The greater wing and body of the sphenoid bone are involved in several important anatomical structures, but they do not contain the optic foramen. Instead, the greater wing contributes to the formation of the superior orbital fissure, through which other nerves and vessels pass. D. Lesser wing of sphenoid and ethmoid: The lesser wing of the sphenoid and the ethmoid bone do not directly form the location of the optic foramen. While the ethmoid bone is located close to the sphenoid in the skull, the optic foramen is strictly located between the lesser wing and the body of the sphenoid, not between the lesser wing and the ethmoid bone.

questions.text: Uncinate process of ethmoid attached anteriorly to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lacrimal bone. The uncinate process of the ethmoid bone is a hook-shaped bony structure that is attached anteriorly to the lacrimal bone. It is part of the nasal cavity anatomy and contributes to the formation of the middle meatus. The uncinate process serves as an important landmark in the anatomy of the paranasal sinuses and the nasal passages. Its attachment to the lacrimal bone is significant in the context of sinus drainage and nasal airflow. Incorrect Options: A. Sphenoid: The sphenoid bone is located posteriorly and superiorly to the ethmoid bone, but it does not have a direct anterior attachment to the uncinate process. The sphenoid's role is more involved in the posterior parts of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses. Hence, the sphenoid is not the correct answer. B. Ethmoid: While the uncinate process is a structure of the ethmoid bone, its anterior attachment is specifically to the lacrimal bone, not the ethmoid itself. The ethmoid bone supports the uncinate process but does not directly serve as its anterior attachment point. C. Frontal: The frontal bone is located above the nasal cavity and does not directly connect to the uncinate process. While the frontal sinus is related to the nasal cavity and ethmoid structures, the uncinate process does not attach to the frontal bone.

questions.text: The Thinnest wall of the human orbit is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Medial wall. The thinnest wall of the human orbit is the medial wall. This wall is composed mainly of the ethmoid bone, which is quite thin and fragile. The medial wall separates the orbit from the nasal cavity and the paranasal sinuses, including the ethmoidal sinuses. Because of its thin structure, the medial wall is more susceptible to fractures, especially in cases of trauma to the orbit. The proximity of the ethmoidal sinuses also contributes to the fragility of this wall. Incorrect Options: A. Roof: The roof of the orbit is primarily formed by the frontal bone and is relatively thick and strong. While it provides a solid structure above the eye, it is not the thinnest wall. The roof also has to support the weight of the frontal sinus and is therefore thicker than the medial wall. C. Floor: The floor of the orbit is formed by the maxillary bone and is somewhat thick as well, especially to support the weight of the face and the structures in the maxillary sinus. While it is not as thick as the lateral wall, it is still thicker than the medial wall, and it is not the thinnest. D. Lateral wall: The lateral wall of the orbit is the thickest and strongest, composed mainly of the zygomatic bone and part of the sphenoid bone. This wall provides structural support and protection to the lateral aspects of the eye, making it much thicker compared to the medial wall.

questions.text: Subarachanoid space ends at
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) S2. The subarachnoid space, which is the space between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater surrounding the spinal cord and brain, extends down to the level of S2 in the vertebral column. Below the L1-L2 vertebral level, the spinal cord itself ends, but the subarachnoid space continues down to the sacral level (S2). This is important clinically, particularly for procedures like lumbar punctures (spinal taps), where the needle is typically inserted between the L3-L4 or L4-L5 vertebrae, below the level where the spinal cord ends, into the subarachnoid space.

questions.text: Following foramina are found in greater wing of sphenoid, except –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Optic canal The optic canal is not located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. It is located in the lesser wing of the sphenoid and transmits the optic nerve (CN II) and the ophthalmic artery. Therefore, the optic canal is not a foramen found in the greater wing of the sphenoid, making option D the correct answer. Incorrect Answers: A. Rotundum The foramen rotundum is located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. It allows passage of the maxillary nerve (V2) from the trigeminal nerve (CN V). This foramen is correctly found in the greater wing of the sphenoid, so option A is incorrect. B. Ovale The foramen ovale is also located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. It transmits the mandibular nerve (V3) from the trigeminal nerve (CN V), along with other structures like the accessory meningeal artery. Thus, option B is incorrect. C. Spinosum The foramen spinosum is situated in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. It transmits the middle meningeal artery and the meningeal branch of the mandibular nerve (V3).

choices.text: Angular vein to ophthalmic vein to cavernous sinus
Dorsal nasal vein to maxillary vein to cavernous sinus
Facial vein to pterygoid plexus to cavernous sinus
Palatine vein to ophthalmic vein to cavernous sinus

questions.text: A patient presented with pustule over the dorsum of nose and upper lip. Which is the most direct route of spread of this infection to cavernous sinus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Angular vein to ophthalmic vein to cavernous sinus The most direct route of infection spread from the face to the cavernous sinus is via the angular vein. The angular vein drains the area around the nose and upper lip, including the dorsum of the nose, and it connects to the ophthalmic vein. The ophthalmic vein directly communicates with the cavernous sinus, a venous sinus located within the skull, making this the primary pathway for an infection from the face to reach the cavernous sinus. The infection can spread via this venous route, potentially causing a serious condition known as cavernous sinus thrombosis. Thus, option A is correct. Incorrect Answers: B. Dorsal nasal vein to maxillary vein to cavernous sinus This option is incorrect because the dorsal nasal vein primarily drains the skin over the nose, but it does not have a direct connection to the maxillary vein. The dorsal nasal vein typically drains into the ophthalmic vein, not the maxillary vein. The maxillary vein drains the deeper facial structures and has less of a direct route to the cavernous sinus. C. Facial vein to pterygoid plexus to cavernous sinus While the facial vein does communicate with the pterygoid plexus, which in turn connects to the cavernous sinus, this route is not the most direct for an infection originating on the dorsum of the nose and upper lip. The angular vein, which directly communicates with the ophthalmic vein and cavernous sinus, represents a more direct pathway for infection spread, making this option less accurate. D. Palatine vein to ophthalmic vein to cavernous sinus This option is incorrect because the palatine vein drains the palatal region and is not directly involved in venous drainage from the dorsum of the nose or upper lip. The more relevant venous pathways for infection in this area are the angular vein and the ophthalmic vein. Therefore, this route is not the most direct.

questions.text: Foramen transversarium transmit -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Vertebral artery The foramen transversarium is a passage found in the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae (typically C1 to C6) through which the vertebral artery, vertebral veins, and sympathetic nerve fibers pass. The vertebral artery travels through the foramen transversarium on its way to enter the cranial cavity, where it ultimately joins the basilar artery, contributing to the blood supply of the brain. Hence, option D is correct. Incorrect Answers: A. Inferior jugular vein The inferior jugular vein is not transmitted through the foramen transversarium. It drains the blood from the head and neck and passes through the neck, but it does not use the foramen transversarium. The jugular veins typically pass through the jugular foramen in the skull, not through the cervical vertebrae. Therefore, option A is incorrect. B. Inferior petrosal sinus The inferior petrosal sinus is a venous structure that drains blood from the brain, specifically from the cavernous sinus, and empties into the internal jugular vein. This sinus does not pass through the foramen transversarium; instead, it travels along the petrous part of the temporal bone. Therefore, option B is incorrect. C. Sigmoid sinus The sigmoid sinus, which drains blood from the brain into the internal jugular vein, does not pass through the foramen transversarium. It is located within the cranial cavity, specifically in the posterior cranial fossa, and exits through the jugular foramen. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

questions.text: The cavernous sinus communicates directly with all except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sigmoid sinus and straight sinus The cavernous sinus does not communicate directly with the sigmoid sinus or the straight sinus. These sinuses are part of the venous drainage system within the cranial cavity but do not have a direct connection with the cavernous sinus. The sigmoid sinus drains into the internal jugular vein, while the straight sinus drains into the confluence of sinuses. The cavernous sinus primarily communicates with structures like the inferior petrosal sinus and pterygoid venous plexus, but it does not have a direct communication with the sigmoid or straight sinuses. Therefore, option D is correct. Incorrect Answers: A. Inferior petrosal sinus The cavernous sinus communicates directly with the inferior petrosal sinus. The inferior petrosal sinus drains the cavernous sinus and carries blood to the internal jugular vein. This venous communication plays a significant role in venous drainage from the brain. Therefore, option A is incorrect. B. Pterygoid venous plexus The cavernous sinus communicates with the pterygoid venous plexus via emissary veins. This venous connection is important in facilitating venous drainage and can serve as a route for the spread of infections from the face and oral cavity to the cavernous sinus. Therefore, option B is incorrect. C. Veins in orbit The cavernous sinus communicates with veins in the orbit, such as the superior ophthalmic vein, which drains into the cavernous sinus. This communication allows venous blood from the orbit to flow into the cavernous sinus, contributing to venous drainage from the eye and surrounding structures.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding mandibular nerve is correct -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Passes through foramen ovale The mandibular nerve (V3), which is the third and largest division of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), passes through the foramen ovale in the sphenoid bone to enter the infratemporal fossa. This foramen serves as the passage for the mandibular nerve as it travels toward its branches, which provide both sensory and motor innervation to structures in the lower face, including the muscles of mastication. Therefore, option C is correct. Incorrect Answers: A. Branch of facial nerve The mandibular nerve is not a branch of the facial nerve. It is one of the three branches of the trigeminal nerve (V), which is responsible for sensory innervation of the face and motor control of the muscles of mastication. The facial nerve (VII), on the other hand, is involved in facial expression and taste sensation but is not responsible for the mandibular nerve’s functions. Therefore, option A is incorrect. B. Purely motor The mandibular nerve is not purely motor; it is a mixed nerve that carries both motor and sensory fibers. The motor fibers innervate the muscles of mastication, while the sensory fibers provide sensation to the lower part of the face, including the skin of the chin, lower lip, and jaw, as well as the teeth, gums, and the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Therefore, option B is incorrect. D. Related to sphenopalatine ganglion The mandibular nerve is not directly related to the sphenopalatine ganglion. The sphenopalatine ganglion, also known as the pterygopalatine ganglion, is associated with the maxillary nerve (V2), another branch of the trigeminal nerve. It is involved in the parasympathetic innervation to the lacrimal glands and the nasal and palatine mucosa.

questions.text: Structures passing through the foramen magnum are-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vertebral artery The vertebral arteries pass through the foramen magnum to enter the cranial cavity, where they join to form the basilar artery. The foramen magnum, a large opening at the base of the skull, is the passage for various important structures, but the vertebral arteries are one of the key vessels that traverse this foramen to supply blood to the brainstem and posterior parts of the brain. Therefore, option B is correct. Incorrect Answers: A. Spinal cord The spinal cord does pass through the foramen magnum, but the question specifically asks for structures related to this foramen in a broader anatomical context. While the spinal cord enters the cranial cavity through the foramen magnum, it is primarily associated with the spinal column, not as an "individual" structure passing through in the sense meant by the other options. This may cause some confusion, but it is important to recognize that the vertebral arteries and associated structures are more directly relevant to the foramen magnum in this context. Therefore, option A is incorrect. C. Internal jugular vein The internal jugular vein does not pass through the foramen magnum. Instead, it forms in the cranial cavity by the union of the inferior petrosal sinus and sigmoid sinus, and it exits the skull through the jugular foramen. Thus, the internal jugular vein is not related to the foramen magnum. Therefore, option C is incorrect. D. IX cranial nerve The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) does not pass through the foramen magnum. It exits the skull through the jugular foramen, not the foramen magnum. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: Which structure passes through infraorbital fissure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Zygomatic nerve. Explanation: Correct Answer: (D) Zygomatic nerve: The zygomatic nerve is a branch of the maxillary nerve (V2), which passes through the infraorbital fissure. This fissure connects the pterygopalatine fossa to the orbit and allows the zygomatic nerve to enter the orbit. The zygomatic nerve then gives off branches, including the zygomaticofacial and zygomaticotemporal nerves, which provide sensory innervation to parts of the face. Incorrect Answers: (A) Superior ophthalmic vein: The superior ophthalmic vein passes through the superior orbital fissure, not the infraorbital fissure. It drains venous blood from the orbit and communicates with the cavernous sinus, but it does not pass through the infraorbital fissure. (B) Ophthalmic artery: The ophthalmic artery passes through the optic canal into the orbit, not through the infraorbital fissure. It supplies blood to the eye and other structures within the orbit. (C) Trochlear nerve: The trochlear nerve (CN IV) passes through the superior orbital fissure, not the infraorbital fissure. It innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, allowing for eye movement.

choices.text: Head of the mandible moves forwards

questions.text: Which is not true about opening of jaw-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Articular disc moves backwards. Explanation: During the opening of the jaw, the articular disc does not move backward. Instead, it moves forward along with the head of the mandible, as part of the hinge movement within the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). The disc and the condyle of the mandible move in unison during jaw opening, which is part of a combined hinge and gliding motion. Therefore, saying that the articular disc moves backward is not accurate in the context of jaw opening. Incorrect responses: A. Lateral pterygoid muscle contracts: This statement is true. The lateral pterygoid muscle plays a key role in the opening of the jaw. It is the primary muscle responsible for depressing the mandible (opening the jaw). When the lateral pterygoid contracts, it pulls the head of the mandible forward, allowing the mouth to open. B. Movement in vertical plane: This is true. The movement of the jaw during opening occurs primarily in a vertical plane. As the mandible moves downward and forwards, the motion is mostly vertical, with some forward displacement due to the combined action of the muscles and the TMJ. D. Head of the mandible moves forwards: This is true. As the lateral pterygoid muscle contracts, it pulls the head of the mandible forward, which is a crucial aspect of the opening mechanism. This forward movement of the mandible head is essential for allowing the jaw to open fully.

questions.text: Which among the following does not pass through superior orbital fissure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Optic nerve. Explanation: The optic nerve (CN II) does not pass through the superior orbital fissure. Instead, it passes through the optic canal, which is a separate structure from the superior orbital fissure. The optic nerve carries visual information from the retina to the brain, and its path is distinct from those structures that traverse the superior orbital fissure. Incorrect responses: A. Oculomotor nerve: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) passes through the superior orbital fissure to supply most of the extraocular muscles (except for the lateral rectus and superior oblique) and the muscles of the eyelid (levator palpebrae superioris). C. Ophthalmic division of trigeminal: The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V1) passes through the superior orbital fissure. It provides sensory innervation to the forehead, upper eyelid, and cornea, among other areas. D. Trochlear nerve: The trochlear nerve (CN IV) also passes through the superior orbital fissure. It innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which helps in downward and inward movement of the eye.

questions.text: The following ligaments are present in temporomandibular joint, except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Alar ligament. Explanation: The alar ligament is not present in the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). The alar ligament is located in the cervical spine, specifically in the upper part of the neck, where it connects the dens of the axis (C2 vertebra) to the occipital condyles. Its primary role is in stabilizing the atlantoaxial joint and limiting rotation of the head. It is unrelated to the TMJ, making it the correct choice as the ligament not present in the TMJ. Why the other options are incorrect: Lateral temporomandibular ligament (Option A) The lateral temporomandibular ligament is an important ligament of the TMJ. It reinforces the joint capsule on the lateral side and helps prevent posterior dislocation of the mandibular condyle. This ligament is critical in stabilizing the TMJ during movements of the jaw, such as opening and closing. Sphenomandibular ligament (Option B) The sphenomandibular ligament is also a ligament of the TMJ. It attaches from the spine of the sphenoid bone to the lingula of the mandible. This ligament helps limit excessive movement of the mandible and provides support during jaw movements. Stylomandibular ligament (Option C) The stylomandibular ligament is another ligament associated with the TMJ. It arises from the styloid process of the temporal bone and attaches to the angle of the mandible. It functions to limit the movement of the mandible and provides support during jaw motion.

questions.text: The roof of the olfactory region is formed by -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cribriform plate of ethmoid. Explanation: The roof of the olfactory region is formed by the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. The cribriform plate is a perforated bony structure located in the superior part of the nasal cavity, through which the olfactory nerves (CN I) pass from the nasal mucosa to the olfactory bulbs in the brain. This plate separates the nasal cavity from the brain, and it is essential for the function of olfaction. The olfactory region is located in the upper part of the nasal cavity, and the cribriform plate serves as the roof for this region. Why the other options are incorrect: Nasal bone (Option A) The nasal bone is part of the external structure of the nose and forms the bridge of the nose. It does not form the roof of the olfactory region. The nasal bone is more involved with the facial skeleton and external features rather than the internal structures like the olfactory region. Sphenoid (Option C) The sphenoid bone is located deep in the skull, and although it is involved in the overall structure of the cranial cavity, it does not form the roof of the olfactory region. It is more associated with the base of the skull and the formation of other sinuses. Temporal bone (Option D) The temporal bone is located on the sides of the skull and is involved in the structure of the ear and the cranial cavity. It does not contribute to the roof of the olfactory region, which is specifically formed by the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone.

questions.text: Dorello’s canal transmits to cavernous sinus -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Abducent nerve. Explanation: Dorello's canal is a small bony canal located in the sphenoid bone near the cavernous sinus. It transmits the abducent nerve (cranial nerve VI) to the cavernous sinus. The abducent nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is responsible for abducting the eye. The abducent nerve travels through Dorello's canal as it enters the cavernous sinus, which is important for its function in eye movement. Therefore, the abducent nerve is the correct structure passing through Dorello's canal to the cavernous sinus. Why the other options are incorrect: Middle meningeal artery (Option A) The middle meningeal artery does not pass through Dorello's canal. Instead, it passes through the foramen spinosum to supply the meninges and other structures in the cranial cavity. It is not associated with Dorello's canal or the cavernous sinus. Mandibular nerve (Option B) The mandibular nerve (V3), a branch of the trigeminal nerve, does not pass through Dorello's canal. It exits the skull through the foramen ovale to supply sensory and motor functions to the lower face, jaw, and muscles of mastication. Therefore, it is not related to Dorello's canal or the cavernous sinus. Superior alveolar branch of maxillary (Option C) The superior alveolar nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve (V2), does not pass through Dorello's canal. It innervates the upper teeth, gums, and parts of the maxilla and enters the infraorbital foramen or the pterygopalatine fossa, not the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: Structures passing through Foramen Rotundum is -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Maxillary nerve. Explanation: The foramen rotundum is an opening in the sphenoid bone that transmits the maxillary nerve (V2), which is the second division of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V). The maxillary nerve provides sensory innervation to the middle portion of the face, including the maxilla, upper teeth, cheeks, nasal cavity, and parts of the palate. It passes through the foramen rotundum to enter the pterygopalatine fossa, where it branches further. Why the other options are incorrect: Oculomotor nerve (Option A) The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) does not pass through the foramen rotundum. Instead, it exits the brainstem at the midbrain and travels through the superior orbital fissure to innervate most of the muscles controlling eye movement. Therefore, the oculomotor nerve does not pass through the foramen rotundum. Trochlear nerve (Option B) The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) also does not pass through the foramen rotundum. It exits the brainstem at the midbrain and enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure to innervate the superior oblique muscle. Hence, it is not associated with the foramen rotundum. Lacrimal nerve (Option C) The lacrimal nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (V1), and it passes through the superior orbital fissure to supply sensory innervation to the lacrimal gland and parts of the eye. Like the oculomotor and trochlear nerves, it does not pass through the foramen rotundum.

questions.text: Structures passing through Foramen Ovale ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mandibular nerve. Explanation: The foramen ovale is an opening in the sphenoid bone of the skull, and it serves as a passage for the mandibular nerve (V3), which is the third division of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V). The mandibular nerve is both a sensory and motor nerve. It provides sensation to the lower face, including the lower jaw, teeth, and part of the tongue, and it also innervates the muscles of mastication (chewing). Thus, the mandibular nerve is the correct structure that passes through the foramen ovale. Why the other options are incorrect: Oculomotor nerve (Option A) The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) does not pass through the foramen ovale. Instead, it exits the brainstem at the level of the midbrain and passes through the superior orbital fissure to innervate most of the eye muscles. Therefore, it is not associated with the foramen ovale. Trochlear nerve (Option B) The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) also does not pass through the foramen ovale. It exits the brainstem at the level of the midbrain and passes through the superior orbital fissure to innervate the superior oblique muscle of the eye. Thus, it is unrelated to the foramen ovale. Lacrimal nerve (Option C) The lacrimal nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (V1), and it passes through the superior orbital fissure. It provides sensory innervation to the lacrimal gland and parts of the eye, but it does not pass through the foramen ovale.

questions.text: Structures passing through jugular Foramen -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Glossopharyngeal nerve. Explanation: The jugular foramen is a large opening located at the base of the skull, through which several important structures pass. One of these structures is the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), which innervates the pharynx and parts of the tongue. The glossopharyngeal nerve has both sensory and motor functions, including taste sensation from the posterior third of the tongue and controlling some muscles of the pharynx for swallowing. In addition to the glossopharyngeal nerve, the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) and accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI) also pass through the jugular foramen, making it a key passage for these cranial nerves. Why the other options are incorrect: Oculomotor nerve (Option A) The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) does not pass through the jugular foramen. It exits the brainstem at the level of the midbrain and passes through the superior orbital fissure to innervate the muscles controlling eye movement. Thus, the oculomotor nerve is unrelated to the jugular foramen. Trochlear nerve (Option B) The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV), like the oculomotor nerve, does not pass through the jugular foramen. It exits the brainstem at the level of the midbrain and also travels through the superior orbital fissure to innervate the superior oblique muscle of the eye. Hence, it is not associated with the jugular foramen. Lacrimal nerve (Option C) The lacrimal nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V1), and it passes through the superior orbital fissure, not the jugular foramen. The lacrimal nerve provides sensory innervation to the lacrimal gland and parts of the eye, but it does not pass through the jugular foramen.

questions.text: Which of the following are draining channels of cavernous sinus-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Inferior petrosal sinus. Explanation: The inferior petrosal sinus is a draining channel of the cavernous sinus. It collects venous blood from the cavernous sinus and drains it into the internal jugular vein. The inferior petrosal sinus acts as an efferent pathway for venous blood, helping to regulate the drainage of blood from the cavernous sinus to the systemic circulation. This venous channel is an essential component of the venous system, specifically in the drainage of blood from the cranial cavity and the brain. Why the other options are incorrect: Inferior ophthalmic vein (Option B) The inferior ophthalmic vein is a tributary of the cavernous sinus, meaning it drains into the cavernous sinus rather than acting as a draining channel. It collects blood from the orbit and the surrounding areas and empties into the cavernous sinus, but it does not drain the cavernous sinus itself. Sphenoparietal sinus (Option C) The sphenoparietal sinus is another tributary of the cavernous sinus. It drains into the cavernous sinus, helping to transport blood from the lateral side of the skull. It does not act as a draining channel for the cavernous sinus. Superior ophthalmic vein (Option D) The superior ophthalmic vein is also a tributary of the cavernous sinus. It drains blood from the orbit, and it also passes into the cavernous sinus. However, it does not drain the cavernous sinus itself. Like the inferior ophthalmic vein, it is involved in carrying blood to the cavernous sinus rather than draining it.

questions.text: Which of the following transmits a nerve branch to the meninges -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Foramen spinosum. Explanation: The foramen spinosum transmits the meningeal branch of the mandibular nerve (nervus spinosus) along with the middle meningeal artery and vein. This nerve branch supplies the dura mater of the cranial cavity, providing sensory innervation to the meninges. The foramen spinosum is located in the sphenoid bone and plays a critical role in the vascular and nervous supply of the meninges, which is essential for maintaining the protective and functional integrity of the brain. Why the other options are incorrect: Mastoid foramen (Option B) The mastoid foramen transmits an emissary vein connecting the sigmoid sinus to the external venous system and occasionally a small branch of the occipital artery. It does not carry a nerve branch to the meninges, making this option incorrect. Jugular foramen (Option C) The jugular foramen transmits cranial nerves IX (glossopharyngeal), X (vagus), and XI (accessory), as well as the internal jugular vein. While the vagus nerve has branches that contribute to the innervation of some dura mater regions, the foramen does not specifically transmit a distinct meningeal nerve branch like the foramen spinosum does. Hence, this option is incorrect in the context of the question. Foramen magnum (Option D) The foramen magnum transmits the medulla oblongata, vertebral arteries, and spinal roots of the accessory nerves. Although structures passing through the foramen magnum indirectly relate to the meninges, it does not transmit a specific meningeal nerve branch, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: A 60 year old man with a known history of lung cancer comes to office due to hoarseness & difficulty in swallowing. He has no disturbance in vision & hearing. On examination there is loss of gag reflex on left side, when the patient is prompted to say “ah”, the uvula deviates to right side. His left shoulder is drooped & strength is reduced during left shoulder shrug testing. Chest X-ray & MRI of head demonstrates multiple lesions consistent with metastasis. A lesion involving which of the anatomical structure is most likely responsible for this patients' symptoms –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) This history reveals the involvement of 9,10 & 11 cranial nerves which pass through the jugular foramen.

questions.text: A benign tumor in the orbit of a 49-year-old man compresses a structure that runs through both the superior orbital fissure and the common tendinous ring. Which of the following structures is most likely damaged?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (d) Abducens nerve passes through both the superior orbital fissure and the common tendinous ring.

questions.text: A patient recovering from a traumatic injury to the face now finds himself unable to chew his food. On physical examination, his jaw deviates to the right side. The nerve that has been injured in this patient exits the skull through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Patient is suffering from Mandibular nerve injury which exits through Foramen ovale.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents to your office with difficulty walking. On physical examination, he has thoracic kyphoscoliosis. Also he has multiple small scars on his hands because he repeatedly accidentally burns his hands because he "cannot feel the heat." Neurologic examination reveals 1+ biceps reflexes and 3+ patellar reflexes bilaterally, as well as decreased muscle strength in the bilateral upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's problems?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This patient presents with both sensory and motor loss bilaterally. Only Syringomyelia can explain this. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis has only motor system involvement. Guillian-barre syndrome has predominantly motor involvement.

questions.text: A 55 years old man , a known case of syphilis complains of problems in walking such as with the legs far apart. Also on Examination, Loss of coordination and reflexes is observed.which of the following explains patients' condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tabes Dorsalis involves the Posterior column pathway which carries information for fine touch, conscious proprioception etc. Tabes dorsalis is seen as complication of syphilis.

questions.text: A middle-aged women complained that her right-hand tremors when she attempts to insert a thread in the eye of sewing needle; and her body sways towards the right side while walking. On physical examination the Physician found that: (a) there is flaccidity of limb muscles on the right side, (b) the patient swayed over to the right side when she was asked to walk on heel to toe along a straight line on the floor, and (c) when she was asked to touch the tip of her nose with her right index finger, the finger tended to overshoot the target. Which part of the Brain is affected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Patient is presenting typical features of cerebellar syndrome.

questions.text: A 56 years old female comes to the Emergency department complaining of difficulty walking that started few hours ago. She also says that she cannot feel her right side. Physical examination reveals loss of touch sensation affecting the right upper and lower extremities and the right side of the face. Her muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities. This patient has most likely suffered a stroke affecting which of the following brain structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Patient is having pure sensory loss and thalamus is biggest relay centre for crude and fine sensations hence Thalamic stroke can explain this condition.

questions.text: During an annual health examination of a 48 years old woman, it is found that there is hyper secretion of norepinephrine from her suprarenal medulla. Which of the following types of nerve fibers are most likely overstimulated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (a) Preganglionic sympathetic fibers stimulate the adrenal medulla directly and which in turn start secreting NE.

questions.text: During a road rage a 22-year-old man is stabbed with an ice pick. The weapon passes through the superior orbital fissure. Which of the following is most likely to be severed as the ice pick passes through this fissure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Everything that innervates orbital structures, other than the optic nerve, passes through superior orbital fissure. This includes the oculomotor nerve (CN III), the trochlear nerve (CN IV), the ophthalmic nerve (V1), and the abducens nerve (CN VI). The facial nerve (CN VII) passes through the internal auditory meatus. The mandibular nerve (V3) passes through the foramen ovale. The maxillary nerve (V2) passes through the foramen rotundum.

questions.text: Joint involved in movement of head left to right is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Joint involved in movement of head left to right is Atlantoaxial joint,also known as "No joint". Option B-Atlanto occipital is also known as "yes joint" Option C,D-C2 – C3 and C3 – C4 have plane synovial joint between articular facets of vertebrae.

questions.text: A patient complains of headache with periorbital pain, tearing/ lacrimation, drooling of saliva, jaw spasm/pain, with light and accommodation reflex normal and pupils neither dilated nor constricted. Features of the patient can be explained by the involvement of which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-A is the optic nerve but light and accommodation reflex are normal.so this nerve is not injured. Option B-B is oculomotor nerve but light and accommodation reflex are normal.so this nerve is not injured. Option C-C is trigeminal nerve which can result in headache with periorbital pain and jaw spasm/pain due to involvement of muscles of mastication. Option D-D is facial nerve but it do not cause jaw spasm/pain.

questions.text: Which is formed by 3 bones?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Foramen Magnum is present in occipital bone. Option B-Foramen jugulare is present between petrous part of temporal bone and occipital bone. Option C-Foramen rotundum is present in sphenoid bone. Option D-Foramen lacerum contributed by petrous part of temporal bone,sphenoid & occipital bone.

questions.text: Which of following structure passes via jugular foramen has separate canal:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-12th Nerve does not pass through jugular foramen rather,it passes through hypoglossal canal. Option B-9th Nerve has a separate canal while passing through jugular foramen. Option C,D-10th and 11 th Nerve passes together through jugular foramen.

questions.text: Identify the marked foramen/canal
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-foramen rotundum is present in greater wing of sphenoid bone as shown in picture,maxillary nerve passes through it. Option B-F.ovale is present in greater wing of sphenoid bone,but as the name suggests it is oval in shape and it lies behind the foramen rotundum, Option C-Vidian canal connects foramen lacerum to pterygopalatine fossa. Option D-Incisive foramen is present on the palatal surface of maxillary bone.

questions.text: Through which of the marked foramen, Covid may spread to meninges ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Covid may spread to meninges through Cribiform plate of ethmoid as shown in label A,from where olfactory nerves are passing, and hence covid can cause meningitis & encephalitis. Option B-Label B is foramen ovale through which mandibular nerve passes. Option C-Label C is internal acoustic meatus through which facial and vestibulocohlear nerve passes. Option D-Label D is jugular foramen through which 9th,10th, and 11th nerve passes.

choices.text: Taste sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue
General sensation from anterior 2/3rd of tongue

questions.text: In case of trauma to jugular foramen which of the following function is lost?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Taste sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue is carried by chorda tympani,branch of facial nerve. Option B-Through jugular foramen, 9th 10th 11th Nerve Are passing through.and we know taste in posterior 1/3rd of tongue is carried by 9th Nerve which passes through jugular foramen. Option C-General sensation from anterior 2/3rd of tongue is carried by lingual nerve,bnranch of mandibular nerve. Option D-All motor function of tongue are carried out by by XII Nerve which passes through hypoglossal canal.

questions.text: Identify the marked nerve in the base of the skull ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-There is nothing known as ocular nerve. Option B-Marked arrow is 3rd nerve i.e,Oculomotor nerve,and Thickest looking is 5th Nerve. Option C-Hypoglossal nerve passes through Hypoglossal canal. Option D-Glossopharyngeal nerve passes through jugular foramen.

questions.text: Which of the following structures lies deep to the marked area
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Posterior clinoid process is present posterior to sella turcica. Option B-The marked area is Pterion –lesser wing of sphenoid lies deeper to it and also Deep to it lies middle meningeal artery. Option C-Carotid canal is present in petrous part of temporal bone. Option D-Sella turcica is present on body of sphenoid.

questions.text: Artery lying deep to the marked area is which one of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Ophthalmic Artery passes through optic canal. Option B-Maxillary Artery lies on lateral pterygoid muscle. Option C-Internal Carotid Artery passes through carotid canal. Option D- The marked area is PTERION -deep to it lies middle meningeal artery : Anterior division.It's rupture is the Most common cause of EDH.

questions.text: SDH is due to injury to which of the following vessel?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Middle Meningeal artery is artery for EDH. Option B-Charcot Artery is artery for CEREBRAL BLEED/ INTRACEREBRAL HEMORRHAGE. Option C-Bridging veins injury leads to subdural hemorrhage. Option D-Middle Cerebral artery leads to intracranial hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which sulcus lies deep to marked area?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The marked area is pterion and Stem of Lateral sulcus lies deep to it. Option B,C,D-Inferior frontal sulcus,Intra Parietal sulcus and Central sulcus are located well away from pterion.

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx
Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face
Loss of sensation in jaw area
Loss of sensation on scalp and nose

questions.text: Which of the following is the clinical presentation, when the nerve passing through the arrow marked region has been lesioned?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx occurs due to injury to nasopalatine nerve. Option B-Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face occurs due to injury to maxillary nerve,which exits via foramen rotundum. Option C-Loss of sensation in jaw area occurs due to injury to greater auricular nerve. Option D-Loss of sensation on scalp and nose occurs due to injury to ophthalmic branch of trigeminal nerve which exits via superior orbital fissure as shown in fissure.

questions.text: Which of the following is marked in given angiogram?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A- The MCA is part of the circle of Willis anastomotic system within the brain, which forms when the anterior cerebral arteries anastomose anteriorly with each other through the anterior communicating artery and posteriorly with the two posterior communicating arteries bridging the MCA with the posterior cerebral artery on each side. Option B-The internal carotid arteries are branches of the common carotid arteries that bifurcate into the internal and external carotids at the level of the carotid sinus.After this bifurcation, the internal carotids traverse through the base of the skull to reach the vital organs that they supply. Option C-Basilar Artery is located on anterior surface of pons. Option D-Your superficial temporal artery sends blood to your scalp and face. It starts below your ear and runs vertically between your cheekbone and your ear.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve is marked in the given picture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 3rd
